Dear Ms. Williams:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
04/19/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MSA
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248)860-0787.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports; access by department, bureau
of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided
to department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and
shall report to the department, when requested, the facts
the department requires with reference to the children upon
forms furnished by the department. Except as otherwise
provided in this subsection and subsection (4), records
regarding children and facts compiled about children and
their parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure
of this information shall be properly safeguarded by the
childcare organization, the department, and any other entity
in possession of the information. Records that are
confidential under this section are available to both of the
following:
Two of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One showed CPS language in the report related to
receipt of the intake.
 A second showed the report listed the child’s birth
mother’s full name.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2020.
R 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all of the following:
(d) Staff qualifications.
The agency requires annual ICHATs for it employees. Two of
eight employee records reviewed where the employee was
employed for over a year did not show compliance:
 Both employee’s annual ICHAT was due in December
2020; and was not completed until 2/24/2022 and
3/28/2022 respectively.
4

R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Three of 14 employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 Two employee records showed the respective evaluation
was completed more than two months after its 12/7/2021
and 12/2021 due date.
 A third record did not show a six-month written
performance evaluation for an employee who changed
positions.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
One of three borrowed home records reviewed did not show
compliance to(c) and (d) as required by the rule.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
(f)-(g):
One of three borrowed home records reviewed showed
documentation that (f) and (g) occurred over a month after the
11/24/2021 borrowed home date.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2020.
5

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance as required by (c).
The evaluation did not show the outcome of the interview with
the foster father related to one of the rule investigated, nor an
interview with the doctor mentioned in the report or exploration
of the outcome the child’s doctor’s visit with that doctor, by way
of the interview with the case worker or a medical report.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
Two of five special evaluations reviewed did not show clear
documentation of the name of the interviewer or where the
person was interviewed.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Two of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rule. The
section of the child’s DHS-69 -Action Summary which would
have shown documentation of this information was left it blank.
6

R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404 (4).
Two of two Initial Service Plans (ISP) reviewed did not show
documentation of (c) as required by the rule.
R400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following:
(g) a child management plan which includes any changes made
since the previous plan and which is to be used by the foster
parents.
Two of 23 Updated Service Plans (USP) reviewed (related to
one foster child’s record), did not document a child specific
behavior management plan.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a February 2022 foster home visit with the
child and caregiver.
R 400.12604 Orientation and application.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for adoption before an adoptive application is
provided. The orientation shall include a review of all of the
following:
(a) Program statement, policies, and procedures.
(c) Services and resources available.
(d) Fees and charges.
(e) Legal process.
7

Two of six adoptive family records reviewed did not show
document the applicant was provided the information outlined in
in(a)- (e).
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2020.
R400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(2) The report shall include the dates and places of contacts and
persons interviewed or observed.
One of six adoptive family records reviewed showed the family’s
initial and updated adoptive family assessment did not contain
dates and places of contact.
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
Five of six adoptive family records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.

FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.

All case contacts must be documented in MISACWIS and

FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
10

individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Three of 25 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:

FOM 722-08 E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
Completion Requirements:
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to

 Three days prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement
change, the caseworker must document:
One of eight open foster child records reviewed, where there
was a replacement, showed the DHS-69 for the child’s 7/1/2021

FOM 722-15 Discharge documents.
The caseworker must provide the following documents to the
child's legal parent/guardian, or to the youth if the youth is age
18 or older or has been legally emancipated, at the time of
closure:
 A certified copy of the child's birth certificate (retain a
copy in the case record).
 The child's social security card. Note: In cases where the
social security number has been verified and
documented per policy, the caseworker must make
efforts to obtain a social security card. •
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of compliance as required by the policy.
11

FOM 801-03 Medical Passports.
Updated Medical Passport:
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward; Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement;
and at reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each
placement and quarterly.
One of eight open foster child record reviewed did not show
consistent documentation of quarterly medical passport as
required by the policy.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.12306(4) Application request.
The agency was provided technical assistance and consultation to the rule and
when foster parents request to close.
R400.12327(4) Special evaluation
 The agency was advised the preliminary findings of evaluations shall not be
documented as occurring on the date of the intake, prior to the completion of
the investigation.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R40012328(2)(d)(ii)(iii) Foster home record.
 The agency was advised that continued utilization of its foster home closing
summary whereby it documents clear placement information related to (d)(ii)
and (ii) may aid it with compliance to the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
12

period.
The incident related to an allegation that the foster father dragged the foster child a
short distant in attempt to get her back home and for her not to run away again.
The foster parent reported he was not trying to hurt the child; and admitted to the
allegation. The foster home was found in violation of the behavior management rule
and a corrective action plan was developed with the foster family.
The agency adhered to all department standards except R400.1237(5)(d) and
722.120(3) as cited in this report.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2021 Interim inspection where it
received the following rule violations:
 R400.12312(4)- Foster parent training.
 R400.12326(1)(i)- Borrowed home.
 R400.12418(2)(b)- Development of services plans.
 R400.12418(3) -Development of service plans.
 R400.12605(1) -Adoptive family evaluation.

 FOM722-03B- Relative engagement and placement.
 FOM 722-06B- Family Team Meeting.
 FOM 722-06G- Effort to Identify and Locate Absent/Putative Parent-Location
Efforts.
 FOM 722-06 H-Timely Entry of Case Contacts.
 FOM 722-06H- Caseworker Contact with Child in out of Home Placement.
 FOM 722-06H- Caseworker Contact with Parent(s)/Guardian(s).
 FOM 722-06H- Caseworker Contact with Child’s Caregiver.
 FOM 722-06I- Maintaining Connections through Visitation and Contact: Sibling
Visitation and Ongoing Interaction.
 FOM 722-08C- Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan and Service
Agreement. (Signatures).
 FOM 722-08E- Foster Care Juvenile/Juvenile Action Plan Summary.
 FOM 722-09- Updated Service Plan: Supervisory Approval.
 FOM 801- Medical Passports.
 FOM 801-1- Health Requirement
 SRM 200- Personnel Training.
The agency made some progress with that corrective action plan but was not
completely successful with the corrective plan. The agency received repeat violations
this inspection as indicated in this report.
13

DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
A safety alert was issued on 4/22/2022 related to a relative placement:
Concern:
The relative did not respond to numerous attempts to complete a home visit for the
annual audit even with agency assistance. The safety of the home or child was not
verified.
Resolution:
The agency worker made a home visit to the relative placement on 4/22/2022 and
verified the child’s well-being and the safety of the home. Additionally, the worker spoke
with the relative related to the relative’s lack of communication with the Analyst; and
advised the relative that the relative is required to respond to the Analyst. The relative
agreed to comply in the future.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a continuation of a regular license.
